theories.card_other: Current that periodically reverses direction. Varies sinusoidally with time. Produced by AC generators. Frequency 50 Hz (Pakistan) or 60 Hz (US). Easier to generate and transmit than DC.
Current flowing in one direction only. Constant or slowly varying magnitude. Produced by batteries, solar cells, rectifiers. Used in electronics, electric vehicles. Cannot use transformers directly.
Maximum value of AC voltage or current. Amplitude of sinusoidal wave. Symbol: V₀, I₀. Instantaneous value varies from -peak to +peak. Related to RMS by factor √2.
Root Mean Square value. Equivalent DC value producing same heating effect. Vrms = V₀/√2, Irms = I₀/√2. What AC meters read. Used in power calculations. Also called effective value.
Average over complete cycle is zero (positive and negative halves cancel). Average over half cycle: Vavg = 2V₀/π. Average of rectified AC (half-wave): Vavg = V₀/π. Form factor relates RMS to average.
Position in cycle at given time. Measured in radians or degrees. Phase difference indicates timing between two AC quantities. In phase: peaks coincide. Out of phase: peaks at different times.

Rotating vector representing AC quantity. Length = amplitude. Rotation rate = angular frequency. Projection on axis gives instantaneous value. Simplifies AC circuit analysis (vector addition instead of trigonometry).
Voltage and current in phase (no phase difference). Obeys Ohm's law at every instant. Power always positive (dissipated as heat). Average power = Vrms × Irms.
Current lags voltage by 90°. Inductor opposes current change. No power dissipated (energy stored and returned). Opposition increases with frequency. Inductive reactance XL = ωL.
Opposition to AC by inductor. Increases with frequency (XL = 2πfL). SI unit: ohm. Zero for DC (f = 0). Used in high-pass filters. Blocks high frequencies more than low.
Current leads voltage by 90°. Capacitor allows AC (charges/discharges) but blocks DC. No power dissipated. Opposition decreases with frequency. Capacitive reactance XC = 1/(ωC).
Opposition to AC by capacitor. Decreases with frequency (XC = 1/(2πfC)). SI unit: ohm. Infinite for DC (f = 0). Used in low-pass filters. Blocks low frequencies more than high.
Contains resistor, inductor, and capacitor in series. Same current through all. Total voltage = phasor sum. Impedance Z = √(R² + (XL - XC)²). Shows resonance phenomenon.
Total opposition to AC in circuit. Combines resistance and reactance. SI unit: ohm. Symbol: Z. Depends on frequency. V = IZ (AC version of Ohm's law).
Angle between voltage and current phasors. tan φ = (XL - XC)/R. Positive: inductive (current lags). Negative: capacitive (current leads). Zero at resonance (in phase).
Ratio of real power to apparent power. cos φ where φ is phase angle. Ranges from 0 to 1. Unity at resonance (φ = 0). Low power factor wastes energy in distribution.
Actual power dissipated in resistance. P = Vrms × Irms × cos φ. SI unit: watt (W). Only component doing useful work. Measured by wattmeter.
Power oscillating between source and reactive components (L, C). Q = Vrms × Irms × sin φ. SI unit: VAR (volt-ampere reactive). No net energy transfer. Burdens power system without doing work.
Product of RMS voltage and current. S = Vrms × Irms. SI unit: VA (volt-ampere). Vector sum of real and reactive power. Used to rate transformers, generators.
Occurs when XL = XC. Impedance minimum (equals R). Current maximum. Voltage and current in phase (power factor = 1). Used in radio tuning, filters. Resonant frequency f₀ = 1/(2π√LC).
Measure of sharpness of resonance. Q = ωL/R = 1/(ωCR). Higher Q means sharper peak, better selectivity. Important in radio receivers. Energy stored / energy dissipated per cycle.
Range of frequencies where power ≥ half maximum. Δf = f₀/Q. Narrow for high Q (selective). Wide for low Q (broad response). Important in communication systems.
Passes low frequencies, blocks high. Made with RC circuit (capacitor to ground). Cutoff frequency fc = 1/(2πRC). Used in audio systems, power supplies. Removes noise.
Passes high frequencies, blocks low. Made with RC circuit (capacitor in series). Cutoff frequency fc = 1/(2πRC). Used to remove DC component. Blocks low-frequency noise.
Passes frequencies within certain range. Made with series RLC circuit. Center frequency at resonance. Used in radio tuning, communication systems. Selects desired signal.
Converts AC to pulsating DC. Half-wave: one diode (conducts half cycle). Full-wave: four diodes (bridge) or two with center-tap. Used in power supplies. Needs smoothing capacitor.
Reducing ripple in rectified DC using capacitor. Capacitor charges to peak, discharges slowly through load. Larger capacitor gives smoother output. Trade-off between ripple and cost.
Three AC voltages 120° out of phase. More efficient for power transmission. Constant power delivery. Used in industry, power generation. Requires three wires (plus neutral).
Easy voltage transformation (transformers). Simple generation (no commutator). Lower transmission losses at high voltage. Self-starting motors. Disadvantages: skin effect, reactive power.
